title: Protocol to develop a microfluidic human corneal barrier-on-a-chip to evaluate the corneal epithelial wound repair process
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
The protocol below describes (1) fabrication of the cornea-on-a-chip, (2) human corneal epithelial (HCEpi) cells and human corneal endothelial (HCEnd) cells seeding to create a corneal-barrier-on-chip, (3) measurement of corneal permeability (trans-epithelial electrical resistance and apparent permeability index), (4) hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining of the stratified corneal epithelium, and (5) immunofluorescent staining of cytokeratin-3 and zona occludens-1 (ZO-1) tight junction protein expression (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Figure 2. Experimental timeline
Detailed overview of key steps on critical days of chip preparation, cells seeding, analysis of barrier function and sections imaging.
Fabrication of cornea-chip
Fabrication of the SU-8 silicon master and its silanization was described in the before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] section (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). Thereafter, this section describes (1) preparation of PDMS, (2) creation of the upper and lower PDMS substrate, and (3) alignment and assembly of the cornea-chip.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2492-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Overview of the process for microfabrication of the cornea-chip
(A) SU8 photoresist is spin-coated on the silicon wafers, patterned by UV exposure, and developed to generate SU8 masters.
(B) Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is cured on the SU8 masters to make microfluidic structures.
(C) The PDMS slabs are peeled off and punched to make access holes and open wells. The lower PDMS slab and the glass substrate bond by oxygen plasma treatment. A porous polycarbonate membrane seals the open well in the lower PDMS slab. The upper PDMS slab is bonded to the lower layer to create the cornea-chip.
Manual mixing and degassing of PDMS
Timing: 1 h
Prepare a degassed mixture of PDMS silicone elastomer base and curing agent for replica molding.
Place an empty disposable plastic cup on a scale with appropriate precision and pour silicone elastomer base and curing agent in a 10:1 (base: curing agent) weight ratio.

Mix silicone elastomer base and curing agent vigorously by hand using a disposable plastic fork for 5 min until PDMS appears white.
Place the cup containing the PDMS mixture in a vacuum desiccator for 30 min.
Remove the cup from the chamber to complete degassing.
Creation of the upper and lower PDMS substrate
Timing: 6 h
Attach a master silicon wafer with desired microfabricated channel features to the bottom surface of a Petri dish (100 mm) using double-sided tape.
Use compressed filtered air to gently blow off dust particles from the silicon master.
Pour 20 g of degassed 10:1 (wt/wt, prepolymer: curing agent) PDMS mixture onto the upper layer master. This produces a 2-mm thick PDMS slab with the features of the upper microchannels.
Pour 10 g of degassed 10:1 PDMS mixture onto the cleaned master of the lower layer. This produces a 1-mm thick PDMS slab with the lower microchannels.
Place the Petri dish with PDMS in a vacuum chamber to degas for 10 min and then on a level surface for 1 h to ensure uniform coverage of the master surface with PDMS.
Cover the Petri dish with a lid and put it in an oven at 80°C for 4 h to fully cure PDMS (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Remove the dish from the oven and allow it to cool to 22°C.
Cut the fully cured PDMS along the edge of the silicon wafer using a scalpel and carefully peel it off.

Make holes through the PDMS slab using hole punchers. Use a 1-mm puncher to make holes through the PDMS slabs, providing access to the central upper and lower cell culture microchannels, respectively. Use a 6-mm puncher to create the “Culture zone” and the “TEER zone”, respectively. Punch these holes from the micropatterned surface of the PDMS slab to ensure precise positioning of the holes relative to the microchannels.
Put magic tape on both sides of the PDMS block and then peel the tape off to clean the surfaces.
Wrap the final PDMS slab in magic tape to keep it clean until use.
Alignment and assembly of the cornea-on-a-chip
Timing: 1 h
Pause point: These devices can be stored at 22°C for up to one month before bonding to glass coverslip.
Peel the magic tape from the lower microchannel slab.
Treat the lower PDMS surface and a coverslip with plasma for 1 min.
Place the lower microchannel slab attached to a coverslip.
Treat the porous membrane surface with plasma for 1 min.
Place the porous membrane surface attached to the lower microchannel slab.
Remove the magic tape from the upper microchannel slab and expose the channel side to plasma for 1 min.
Overlay the upper microchannel slab on the membrane (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
When alignment is complete, press down the upper PDMS slab to eliminate trapped air pockets and to ensure firm contact between layers.
Insert the blunt needles into the four ports of the side microchambers.
Cut four pieces of silicone tubing to a length of 8 cm and connect them to the free ends of the needles.
Mix 5 min epoxy on a clean surface and apply it around each needle.
Wait for 30 min to allow the applied epoxy to set.
Preparation of the cornea-on-a-chip
Timing: 3.5 h

This section describes the preparation of the chip before cell seeding, including (1) chip sterilization, (2) channel hydrophilic treatment, and (3) extracellular matrix (ECM) pre-treated chip (preparation details are available in the materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section).
Transfer the chip into a biosafety cabinet and irradiate with UV light for 30 min for sterilization.
Add 100 μL of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) to the chip’s upper and lower inlets, add 50 μL of PBS to the middle chamber of the chip, and perform dynamic processing on a shaker for 5 min, with a rocking angle of at least 30 degrees.
Dilute collagen solution to 10 μg/cm2 with a sterile diluting solution.
Add the 40 μL of diluted collagen solution to the upper and lower layers of the chip, respectively, and 20 μL of diluted collagen solution to the middle chamber.
Allow the chip to coat in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 2 h.
Transfer the chip into a biosafety cabinet, aspirate any remaining collagen solution from the chip and air-dry for 30 min.
Rinse once with Complete Medium, and the chips are now ready for use or store at 4°C for later use.
Note: Pre-coated chips can be prepared and stored for one week at 37°C with 100 μL of PBS. Make sure to seal the chips with parafilm to avoid collagen from drying out.
Critical: The collagen formation is critical for the growth of cells.
Cell seeding and 3D co-culture
Timing: 16 days
This section describes the seeding of HCEpi and HCEnd cells onto the chip to create a corneal-barrier-on-chip model. Considering the physiological characteristics of the human cornea and the feasibility of in vitro cell culture, the seeding density of corneal cells is 6 × 104 HCEpi cells and 1 × 104 HCEnd cells per chip.
Day 1

Timing: 40 min
Discard the supernatant and wash the cells with PBS three times.
Add 1 mL of 0.25% EDTA-Trypsin into the flask of the HCEnd cells (at least 90% confluency).
Transfer the flask into an incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 min.
Add 3 mL of Prigrow I Complete Medium to stop digestion.
Transfer the flask’s content into a 15 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min.
Count the cells and adjust the concentration of the cell suspension to 5 × 105 cells/mL.
Before cells seeding, add 20 μL of Prigrow I Complete Medium to the middle chamber, and then add 20 μL of HCEnd cells suspension in the lower inlet channel.
Quickly check the cells using microscope and then transfer the inverted chip into a horizontal position in the incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Critical: Once cells are seeded into the chip, do not move the chip until the next medium change (24 h later), to allow the growth of cells.
Critical: The endothelial cells do not grow out as efficiently.
Day 2
Timing: 40 min
Discard the supernatant and wash the cells with PBS three times.
Add 1 mL of 0.25% EDTA-Trypsin into the flask of the HCEpi cells (at least 90% confluency).
Transfer the flask into an incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 2 min.
Add 3 mL of DMEM/F12 Complete Medium to stop digestion.
Transfer the flask’s content into a 15 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min.
Count the cells and adjust the concentration of the cell suspension to 3 × 106 cells/mL.
Aspirate the medium from the lower outlet and refresh with 100 μL pre-warmed Prigrow I Complete Medium in the lower channel.

Add 20 μL of HCEpi cells suspension in the upper hole.
Transfer the chip to the incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Critical: Once cells are seeded into the chip, do not move the chip until the next medium change (24 h later), to allow the growth of cells.
After the HCEpi cells proliferation on the membrane, the culture medium is gently aspirated from the upper hole, and the air is then filled in the epithelial compartment to create an air-liquid interface.
The lower channels are introduced into the DMEM/F12 Complete Medium and Prigrow I Complete Medium mix (1:1) at a continuous flow condition with a volumetric flow rate of 100 μL/h by using a programmable low-pressure syringe pump.
Maintain above conditions for 14 days and allow the HCEpi cells to grow until to form a stratified epithelium consisting of five to seven stacked cell layers.
Physiological phenotypes of the microengineered cornea
Timing: 3–4 h
This section describes (1) measurement of transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER), (2) permeability coefficient (Papp) of the corneal-barrier-on-chip model, (3) staining of paraffin sections of stratified corneal epithelium, and (4) immunofluorescence staining of the corneal cells.
Measurement of transepithelial electrical resistance
Timing: 1–2 h
Sterilize the Millicell-electrical resistance system (Millicell-ERS) with 75% ethanol before placing it into the biosafety cabinet.
Connect the probe to the Millicell-ERS.
Sterilize the probe by submerged in 75% ethanol for 15 min.
Prepare the cornea-chip by removing the medium from the basal compartment.
Add 100 μL of PBS to the apical and basal compartments.
Prepare a blank sterilized microdevice without cells and inject PBS into the upper and lower culture channels.
Set the function switch to “Ohms”.
Remove the probe from 75% ethanol and drip it off the electrode tips.
Wash the electrode tips in PBS.

Insert the long electrode tip into the “TEER zone”.
Lower the probe until the long electrode tip touches the bottom of the well.
Keep the short electrode tip above the “Culture zone” surface.
Measure the resistance on the blank microdevice and record the value (Rblank).
Measure the resistance on the cornea-chip and record the value (Rtotal) (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2492_3.csv
Remove the PBS from the apical and basal compartments.
Reconnect the microdevice to the low-pressure syringe pump and perfuse the lower channels with mixed culture medium at a volumetric flow rate of 100 μL/h.
Incubate at a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator.
Note: Keep the probe at a 90° angle. Allow time for the values to level off. Perform the TEER measurement procedure ideally within 5–10 min to ensure the optimal integrity of the cultures. If the device contains different media conditions, wash the probe with 75% ethanol and PBS between the readings. This protocol refers to the User Guide of Millicell® ERS-2 Electrical Resistance System.

Measurement of permeability coefficient
Timing: 2 h
Critical: When aspirating solution or collecting medium, ensure there are sufficient medium remaining over the pod vias to avoid introducing bubbles at this step.
Stop the syringe pump, and aspirate the medium from the outlet.
Incubate cells with hanks balanced salt solution (HBSS) to equilibrate for 20 min in the incubator.
Replace the solution with 100 μL of 100 μg/mL fluorescently labeled dextran (FITC-dextran).
Aspirate out the solution from the lower compartment and refresh with 100 μL HBSS.
20 μL of samples collect from the basal side at time 0 and 60 min.
Prepare a calibration curve of serial dilution range of 0.39–100 μg/mL FITC-dextran. HBSS serves as the zero standard (0 μg/mL).
The fluorescence intensity measurement of FITC-dextran is performed by a hybrid multi-mode microplate reader (excitation/emission wavelengths: 488/525 nm).
Plot a graph with the fluorescence intensity measurements as the dependent variable (Y-axis) and the known concentration of FITC-dextran as the independent variable (X-axis), resulting in an equation formatted as follows: Y = 0.1203X + 0.0078 (R2 = 0.9987), where solving for X determines the FITC-dextran concentration of the sample. (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Prepare a blank device as a control, whose data is subtracted from all readings before data analysis.

Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the paraffin sections of corneal epithelium
Timing: 2 days
The stratified corneal epithelium on the membrane is carefully removed from the PDMS device for further processing.
Add 1 mL 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) to the membrane to fix for 30 min.
Rinse with PBS three times gently and incubate in PBS for 12 h at 4°C.
For tissue dehydration, use 70% ethanol—80% ethanol—95% ethanol—100% ethanol each for 30 min, then in 100% ethanol for another 45 min twice, to gradually remove water from the tissue.
The dehydrated film is incubated with xylene for 30 min to be transparent.
Transfer to a mixture of molten paraffin wax for incubation at 56°C for 30 min and then in 100% molten wax for another 60 min twice.
After embedding, the membrane is sectioned into slices of 3 μm in thickness.
The paraffin-embedded sections are deparaffinized first in a clearing agent and rehydrated from high-to-low-concentration ethanol.
Rinse with distilled water for 1 h.
Place the slides with the section in a metal staining rack.
Immerse sections in the hematoxylin for 1 min.
Remove the rack to a beaker with tap water.
Exchange tap water until the water is clear.
Immerse sections in the eosin for 40 s.
Remove rack to a beaker with tap water.
Exchange tap water until the water is clear.
The slides are rinsed with 95% ethanol twice for 1 min each, 100% ethanol for 1 min, and the clearing agent for 1 min.
Mount coverslip onto the section on the glass slide.
The slides are photographed by a Zeiss Axio Observer microscope (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).

Figure 5. Characterization of human corneal epithelium culture on-chip
(A) H&E images on the stratified corneal epithelium in different conditions after 14 days. “Chip (Epi-ALI)” represents HCEpi cells cultivate in the cornea-chip with an air-liquid interface (ALI) condition. “Chip” represents HCEpi cells and HCEnd cells co-cultivate in the cornea-chip with a suitable condition. Red dotted lines and numbers indicate the thickness of the stratified corneal epithelium.
(B) Immunofluorescence images of cytokeratin-3 expression in the corneal epithelial cells.
(C) Immunohistochemical analysis of tight-junction protein expression shows the lattice-like structure of the epithelial typical tight junction between cells.
Critical: Keep same intensity settings between all conditions and for different slides.
Immunofluorescence staining of specific corneal epithelium protein and intercellular junctions
Timing: 2 days
After 14 days, the membrane is carefully removed from the PDMS device.
Incubate the membrane in 4% PFA for 30 min at 22°C.
Rinse with ice-cold PBS three times gently.
Place the membrane on glass slides.
Draw a circle around the membrane with a histochemical pen to prevent the solution flow away.
Add 0.25% Triton X-100 for 10 min at 22°C.
Wash cells in PBS three times for 5 min.
Block by 1% BSA for 1 h.
Dilute the primary cytokeratin 3 antibody in antibody diluent at 1/100 dilution for use.
Dilute the secondary Cy5-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG antibody in antibody diluent at 1/200 dilution for use.
Dilute the primary ZO1 antibody in antibody diluent at 1/500 dilution for use.
Dilute the secondary FITC conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody in antibody diluent at 1/200 dilution for use.
Incubate cells in the diluted primary cytokeratin 3 antibody in a humidified chamber 12 h at 4°C.
Decant the solution and wash the cells three times in PBS, 5 min each.

Incubate cells with the diluted secondary Cy5-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG antibody for 1 h at 22°C in the dark.
Decant the secondary antibody solution and wash the cells three times with PBS for 5 min each in the dark.
Incubate cells in the diluted primary ZO1 antibody in a humidified chamber for 12 h at 4°C.
Decant the solution and wash the cells three times in PBS, 5 min each.
Incubate cells with the diluted secondary FITC conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody for 1 h at 22°C in the dark.
Decant the secondary antibody solution and wash the cells three times with PBS for 5 min each in the dark.
Incubate cells with 2 mg/mL 4′, 6′-diamidino-2-phenylindole hydrochloride (DAPI) for 10 min at 22°C in the dark to stain the nucleus.
Add coverslip with fluorescent mounting medium for 5 min in the dark.
Photo the cells with a Zeiss Axio Observer fluorescent microscope (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B, 5C, and 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
